raw_text:
Hong Kong in 2011 World Cup bid
 
 Hong Kong is hoping to join Japan as co-host of the 2011 Rugby World Cup.
 
 Japan has applied to host the tournament on its own, with the aim of taking it outside rugby's traditional strongholds for the first time. But Hong Kong Rugby Football Union (HKRFU) chairman John Molloy has called for the territory to host one of the pools and a quarter-final. The Japanese Rugby Football Union (JRFU) says it has yet to receive a formal presentation from the HKRFU. "At this stage, we are only considering hosting the event by ourselves," said JRFU secretary Koji Tokumasu. "We cannot examine any proposal unless we get it in a definitive form." Japan faces stiff competition in the form of South Africa and New Zealand to host the event in seven years' time.
 
 "Until now, the World Cup has been held in countries from the Six Nations or Tri-Nations," said Tokumasu. "We think, and the IRB thinks, that it is time for rugby to go global. "Japan is ready to host the tournament and we are looking forward to welcoming the world of rugby to Japan." Tokumasu added that the 2002 football World Cup, co-hosted by Japan and South Korea, had been a huge success. "As well as having the infrastructure in place, Japan also has the commercial clout to host one of sport's top competitions," he said. Last year, Japan launched its first professional rugby league and it has the fourth largest number of registered players (125,508) in the world after England, South Africa and France.
llama3.2:1b: Hong Kong is bidding for a spot in the 2011 Rugby World Cup as a co-host with Japan, potentially hosting one pool or quarter-final. The Japanese RFU is currently considering whether to host alone, but has yet to receive a formal proposal. Hong Kong's chairman hopes to secure a spot by 2008.
llama3.2:3b: Hong Kong is seeking to co-host the 2011 Rugby World Cup with Japan, with Hong Kong proposing to host one of the pools and a quarter-final. The Japanese Rugby Football Union has not yet received a formal presentation from the HKRFU and is considering hosting the event alone due to stiff competition from other countries, including South Africa and New Zealand.
gemma2:2b: Hong Kong is seeking to co-host the 2011 Rugby World Cup with Japan. The Hong Kong Rugby Football Union wants to host a pool and a quarterfinal, while Japan intends to host the event independently. Japan faces competition from South Africa and New Zealand for hosting rights. The Japanese Rugby Football Union believes it is time for rugby to go global and cites the success of the 2002 World Cup co-hosted by Japan and South Korea as evidence of its ability to host such a prestigious tournament.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Hong Kong hopes to host the 2011 Rugby World Cup as a co-host with Japan. However, Japan is yet to formally present their proposal for hosting the tournament, citing potential financial and logistical difficulties. Tokumasu, chairman of the Hong Kong Rugby Football Union (HKRFU), states that they are only considering hosting in one pool or a quarter-final this time. The 2014 football World Cup was successful as it included infrastructure, commercial clout, and a large number of players from England, South Africa, and France.

Source: 
https://www.theguardian.com/globalnews/2013/aug/19/russia-irb-world-cup-rugby-federation-japan-hong-kong-irb

Note:
- The Rugby World Cup has been hosted in Japan since 1950.
- In the past, South Africa and New Zealand have hosted the tournament before.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Hong Kong aims to co-host the 2011 Rugby World Cup with Japan due to the country's growing rugby popularity and infrastructure capabilities. The Japanese government is considering hosting alone but needs a formal proposal from Hong Kong before it can proceed.
qwen2.5:3b: Hong Kong is hoping to co-host the 2011 Rugby World Cup with Japan. HKRFU chairman John Molloy suggests hosting one pool and a quarter-final match. While JRFU secretary Koji Tokumasu says they are only considering hosting by themselves, Tokyo believes it's time for rugby to go global after successfully hosting the 2002 football World Cup jointly with South Korea. Japan has more than 125,000 registered players and commercial clout.

The JRFU secretary, Koji Tokumasu, notes that Japan is competing with South Africa and New Zealand for the spot. They've been preparing since before the tournament started, which suggests a lot of planning and effort. Japan is ready to host, especially since they've already organized their first professional rugby league with 125,508 players and led the top rankings after last year's tournament. They aim to integrate into the international scene for a successful World Cup. South Korea was also involved in the 2002 Co-Hosting World Cup, which helped Japan succeed there.

So, putting it all together, Hong Kong is considering hosting the 2011 Rugby World Cup as one of their pools and a quarter-final after not having formal approval yet. They need to get a proposal in place before making other decisions.

They need a definitive proposal to proceed with hosting by themselves or in a separate pool and quarter-final. Their transition to the traditional sports areas hasn't been completed yet, making this move crucial. The International Rugby Board (IRB) sees rugby as a potential global movement. Japan aims to host, having organized their first professional league, which placed them at the top rankings globally. This includes South Korea's involvement in the 2002 Co-Hosting World Cup.
